description.text: A panoramic view of Dalhousi. Houses, trees and hills can be seen. Different shades of green, sky blue roofs of houses are visible and soil-brown pathways lead to the inhabited area.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

ext:item.ext:value: description-en: A panoramic view of Dalhousi. Houses, trees and hills can be seen. Different shades of green, sky blue roofs of houses are visible and soil-brown pathways lead to the inhabited area. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The European sections within a hill station were at a higher elevation than the native sections, and the European and native quarters were clearly segregated from each other. The reason given for such distinctions in elevation and segregation was medical. Diseases were seen to accompany migrant Indian workers, hence the need to segregate them. And since the natives were deemed to have a natural tendency to huddle together, the native sections were left unsanitary and overcrowded, thereby jeopardizing the healthful purpose for the hill stations. Unsanitary conditions led to public health hazards, since disease does not respect racial lines and there were many epidemics in the hill stations. It can be concluded that the medical reasons for segregation were in actuality much less important than ideological ones. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-19. (gs)

Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714.

Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press.
Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230.
Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-19.

The European sections within a hill station were at a higher elevation than the native sections, and the European and native quarters were clearly segregated from each other. The reason given for such distinctions in elevation and segregation was medical. Diseases were seen to accompany migrant Indian workers, hence the need to segregate them. And since the natives were deemed to have a natural tendency to huddle together, the native sections were left unsanitary and overcrowded, thereby jeopardizing the healthful purpose for the hill stations. Unsanitary conditions led to public health hazards, since disease does not respect racial lines and there were many epidemics in the hill stations. It can be concluded that the medical reasons for segregation were in actuality much less important than ideological ones.
